item.title: Remembering the New Frontier: A Vintage Las Vegas Icon's Rise & Fall
item.description:
From Frontier to New Frontier: A Wild West Start

The Frontier Hotel and Casino, originally simply “Frontier Hotel,” holds a significant place in the history of the Las Vegas Strip. Opened in 1942 by William “Guy” McAfee and Irv Burton, it was intentionally designed to evoke the feeling of the American West. Unlike the glitz and glamour of downtown, the Frontier aimed for a rustic, adventurous atmosphere, with wooden facades, swinging saloon doors, and a Wild West theme. This was a deliberate choice; it appealed to a broader demographic, particularly families and middle-class tourists, and helped solidify the Stripâ€™s identity as an entertainment destination beyond the more established downtown casinos. The Frontier quickly became a popular destination, boasting 60 rooms and a bustling casino.
